case_vignette: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Initially, the vomitus was food that he had recently eaten, but it is now bilious. He has had similar complaints several times in the past 6 years. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks 24 oz of alcohol daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 48 kg (105 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an epigastric mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

No, I haven't mentioned taking any medications.
Considering your symptoms and the recurrent nature of the episodes, do you have any history of gastrointestinal diseases like gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, or pancreatitis?
I haven't mentioned any history of gastrointestinal diseases.

I haven't mentioned any family history of gastrointestinal conditions.

Given your symptoms, history of alcohol use, and the recurrent nature of the abdominal pain, further investigations such as blood tests and abdominal imaging like an ultrasound are typically indicated to confirm the diagnosis.
